title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges the rapid increase in Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) in the U.S., with rates now at 1 in 150, constituting an epidemic. The number of autism cases continues to rise, surpassing diagnoses of AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. The financial burden of autism on the nation exceeds $35 billion annually and is expected to rise. The current support systems are inadequate to address the challenges posed by autism. The autism epidemic is a significant concern, with rates increasing rapidly in the U.S. The lack of adequate support systems and funding for research hinders progress in understanding and addressing autism spectrum disorders. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated substantial funding for research, but more investment is needed to advance scientific study and support services. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 aims to advance scientific study and analysis of cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 authorizes the conference. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating autism in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing will plan and conduct the Conference to find the causes of autism, provide solutions and services for autistic individuals and families, and involve scientific experts in the process. The White House Conference on Autism aims to bring together scientific minds to research environmental triggers, engage parents and leaders in education and social services, showcase effective programs, and review existing legislation for improvements. The White House Conference on Autism focuses on enhancing the health and well-being of autistic individuals and their families through bills and programs. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members selected by the President, House Speaker, House minority leader, and Senate. Members include officers or employees of the United States and individuals with experience in addressing autism spectrum disorders. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Senate appointees must be selected by majority and minority leaders, with 50% drawn from private industry, nonprofit sector, or academia. Special qualifications include knowledge about autism intervention programs and systems. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Senate appointees must be selected by majority and minority leaders, with 50% drawn from private industry, nonprofit sector, or academia. Special qualifications include knowledge about autism intervention programs and systems. The Committee members must have expertise in programs for educational, housing, law enforcement training for autism, and environmental/toxic exposure related to autism development. The Surgeon General serves as the chairperson and can only vote to break a tie. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Senate appointees must be selected by majority and minority leaders, with 50% drawn from private industry, nonprofit sector, or academia. Special qualifications include knowledge about autism intervention programs and systems. The Committee members must have expertise in programs for educational, housing, law enforcement training for autism, and environmental/toxic exposure related to autism development. The Surgeon General serves as the chairperson and can only vote to break a tie. The Policy Committee shall meet at the call of the Cochairs, make recommendations for the Conference agenda and delegates, establish the number of delegates, and create an executive committee to work with Conference delegates. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in the field of autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States.

SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide notice to the Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other federal departments, make proposed agendas public, provide background materials, and hire additional personnel as needed. The Cochairs, in carrying out their responsibilities, ensure that the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register, personnel are balanced in viewpoints, recommendations are independent, and statistical data is current before the Conference is convened. The Cochairs may obtain statistical data and information on autism spectrum disorders in the United States to evaluate Federal programs. They can accept gifts to support the implementation of this Act, with records maintained on the sources and uses of gifts accepted. The Cochairs can receive assistance to carry out the Act, and must disclose the recipients and amounts received. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE.

The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state CEOs. Within 45 days, CEOs must submit their views on the report. A final report must be prepared within 6 months, including state CEOs' views, and recommendations for administrative action and legislation to be published and sent to the President and Congress.

SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS.

The Surgeon General must prepare an initial status report within 2 years of the Conference adjournment, documenting the implementation of recommendations from the final report. Subsequent status reports must be prepared by the Comptroller General every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. These reports will be published in the Federal Register and transmitted to the President and Congress.

SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. Authorization is granted for necessary appropriations to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated or received as gifts shall remain available for one year after the Conference adjourns. Any unexpended funds from the Conference must be returned to the Treasury if not used within a year. If the Conference does not occur before December 31, 2010, a trust fund will be established for future Autism Conferences.
